Black and Blue Expected to Defeat
Pennsylvania Swimmers

and Blue swimming team will
clash with the Lehigh natators at
the Baltimore Athletic Club. A
dance, the music for which will be
supplied by the Black and Blue
Jay Six, will follow the meet.
Judging from past performances
Johns Hopkins should repulse the
invaders. The Lehigh aggregation
is reported to be strong in the
dive and the breast stroke. The
relay team of visitors has also
proved itself formidable and is expected to give the Hopkins team
keen competition. Perhaps Lehigh's best performer in the pool
is Raleigh, who excels in the back
stroke and the dashes.
Fitzgerald Dunning, captain of
the Hopkins mermen, S-tated that
the local relay team is hoping to
break its own record set at the
meet with the Catholic University.
The line-up for the meet tonight
is •as follows:
100-Yard Breast Stroke—Swanson, Dunning.
100-Yard Swim—Welsh, Lord,
or Bahlke.
40-Yard Dash—Welsh, Lord.
100-Yard Back Stroke — McCleary, Hambleton.
Dive—Stone, Calhoun.
Plunge--Howard, Hambleton.
220-Yard Swim—Bahlke, Stone.
Relay—Bahlke, Duning, Lord,
Welsh.
INSPECTORS AWAITED BY
R. 0. T. C. UNIT
As announced by Major Hoisington, commander of the Johns
Hopkins R. 0. T. C. unit, last
Thursday, February 21, the preliminary inspection of the War
Department to determine whether
the local unit is worthy of being
formally inspected in May will be
held during one of the drill periods of this week. The unit was
told by Major Hoisington to be
prepared fully for inspection at
both the Monday and Thursday
drill periods, as the officers from
Washington had not as yet decided as to which one Johns Hopkins
would be examined on.
This inspection is very important to the R. 0. T. C. Unit, as a
favorable report by the examining
officers will entitle it to an inspection to determine whether or not
Johns Hopkins University should
be designated in War Department
orders and publications as one of
the "Distinguished
Colleges."
This honor the University now
holds.
These preliminary inspections
are given by the War Department
in universities throughout the
country, so that the number of colleges to be examined in May is
fewer, and hence a more careful
and exhaustive inspection may be
given to each one.

dinner of the Y. M. C. A. will be
held at the Friends' Meeting
House, 3107 N. Charles Street, on
Tuesday, March 4, at 6:00 P. M.
Reservations can be made at the
"Y" Office at the Barn. The subscription is $.50 per plate.
Mr. Norman Thomas of New
York City will be the speaker.
His subject will be "The Labor
Movement and the Student." Mr.
Thomas is a graduate of Princeton University and of the Union
Theological Seminary. He has
been editor of "The World Tomorrow" and is now one of the
contributing editors of "The Nation". Mr. Thomas has a full understanding of his subject, according to Mr. Schall, "Y" secretary, for his writings have been
largely on labor topics, and, moreover he is head of "The League
for Industrial Democracy." Mr.
Schall says that the program for
this meeting should surpass any
previous one.
The annual election of the four
chief officers of the Y. M. C. A.
will take place as usual on March
The voting will be at the "Y"
office between the hours of 10:00
A. M. and 5:00 P. M., and from
5:00 P. M. to 6:00 P. M. at the
Friends Meeting House. The results will be made public at the
fellowship dinner.
The number of students present
nt the previous dinners makes it
imperative that the tickets be secured in advance.
Only those
that have .signed up at the "Y"
office before Monday afternoon
will be provided for.
BARNSTORMERS
HOLDING
SIX REHEARSALS A
WEEK AT BARN
Preparations for "The Galloper", by Richard Harding Davis,
to be presented at the Lyric by
the Hopkins Barnstormers' Club
on March 28 and 29, are proceeding at the rate of almost one rehearsal a day. To be exact. rehearsals are being held six times
a week.
Thus far, hov,cver, tt:e rehearsals have been more in the nature
of tryouts. According to present
indications, the two casts will not
be chosen within a week at least.
The Club's recently adopted plan
of casting provides that the final
cast will not be chosen until
about two weeks before the show
is given. Until then, the rehearsals will be in the nature of a
fight between the two casts.
Although a very satisfactory
number of men have responded
to the call for candidates, there
are still opportunities -open to a
number of would-be actors. The
feminine roles, especially, offer
good openings for any embryonic
Julian Eltinges.
Any belated Barrymores who
feel the call of the footlights can
yet show their wares at the tryouts. The rehearsal days are the
following: Monday, Tuesday,
Thursday, and Friday at 7:30 P.
M.; Saturday afternoon at 2
o'clock and Sunday afternoon at
3 o'clock.

When Louis Clarke entered
Johns Hopkins a few years ago,
few realized he was an athlete.
After scrubbing for a year on the
baseball team, the track management persuaded him to try out for
the track team. He succeeded in
breaking all Hopkins records for
the 100 and 220 yard dashes. Last
Saturday night, Clarke reached
the height of his career when he
broke the world's indoor mark for
100 yards when he flew over this
distance in 9 4-5 seconds. In barely three years a sprinter of record
ability was developed by Hopkins
track coaches.

ALUMNI REUNION HELD ON
EVENING OF FEBRUARY 22
The annual Alumni Reunion
held in the Alumni Memorial Dormitory on the evening of February 22 was a decided success. Not
quite as many of the "old grads"
showed up as were counted on,
but 160 made their appearance and
enjoyed to the fullest extent the
program of entertainment provided.
The Commons Hall of the Dormitory was tastefully and colorfully decorated with the class banners of graduating classes as far
back as '80 and '84. Here and
there were banners that showed
all too plainly the ravages of class
rushes and of time but all waved
proudly in the eddy of conversation and reminiscences that
poured unrestrained from the old
timers as well as the youngsters of
'22 and '23.
The principal speakers of the
evening were Dr. Weed, Dean of
the 'Medical School; Mr. Stuart
Janney; Dr. John Latane, retiring
Dean of the University; and Mr.
George Knapp. A short business
meeting was held at which Mr.
Robertson Griswold was elected
President of the Alumni Association. Music and smokes rounded
out a fully pleasurable evening.

BALTIMORE

It is a pity that all universities
not enjoying the Honor System
cannot send committees to investigate its workings at Johns Hopkins, Princeton, Washington and
Lee, and other institutions where
it has proved a success. The recent midyear examinations in
many colleges has again brought
the subject to the fore. A few
headlines from various papers
will show how grave a problem
cheating is in a very great many
colleges. For instance, "Faculty
Acts on Cheating in Exams," "Six
Men Brought Before Faculty
Committee" and "Reports Entirely Cribbed." These are from papers in colleges that enjoy very
good reputations. Yet at N. Y. U.
four members of the faculty profesed the belief that an Honor
System was not only impractical,
but undesirable.

PLAYSHOP INVITES UNDERGRADUATES TO SHOP
NIGHT
The Homewood Playshop will
hold, on Saturday March 1, its
third "Shop Night" of the year.
Several theatrical experiments
will be tried out. These "Shop
Nights" of the Playshop are the
Hopkins Theatrical laboratory periods. All members of the Playshop are invited and all undergraduates will be welcomed.
The Plays that will be tried out
are as follows: "Maneaters" by
McCauley; "The Fruit" by Gilbert Pouder ; and one act from a
Shakespearean play. With all the
dramatic talent now enrolled
under the Hopkins Playshop a
more than delightful evening may
be expected by visitors as the directorial and coaching staffs have
spent more than the ordinary
amount of time in the production
of these excellent playlets.

DEENGINEERING
CIVIL
PARTMENT PROMISES COOPERATION IN ENGINEERING SHOW
The committee in charge of the
Engineering Show has recently
obtained from Prof. John H. Gregory, head of the Civil Engineering
Department, permission to put on
display all of the engineering apparatus belonging to that department. By means of this arrangement, the show as originally
planned will be augmented to almost twice its size. William
North Crout, president of the
American Society of Civil Engineers, who has been placed in
charge of the Civil Engineer's portion of the show, anounced that all
laboratories will be kept open during the two days of the shows In
the Highways Laboratory, there
will be run a number of standard
tests, such as the Dorey test for
hardness of paving material, the
Page impact test, and the Rattler
abrasion test. Samples of bituminous road materials and samples
of Portland cements will also be
put on display.

Black and Blue Expected to Defeat
Pennsylvania Swimmers

and Blue swimming team will
clash with the Lehigh natators at
the Baltimore Athletic Club. A
dance, the music for which will be
supplied by the Black and Blue
Jay Six, will follow the meet.
Judging from past performances
Johns Hopkins should repulse the
invaders. The Lehigh aggregation
is reported to be strong in the
dive and the breast stroke. The
relay team of visitors has also
proved itself formidable and is expected to give the Hopkins team
keen competition. Perhaps Lehigh's best performer in the pool
is Raleigh, who excels in the back
stroke and the dashes.
Fitzgerald Dunning, captain of
the Hopkins mermen, S-tated that
the local relay team is hoping to
break its own record set at the
meet with the Catholic University.
The line-up for the meet tonight
is •as follows:
100-Yard Breast Stroke—Swanson, Dunning.
100-Yard Swim—Welsh, Lord,
or Bahlke.
40-Yard Dash—Welsh, Lord.
100-Yard Back Stroke — McCleary, Hambleton.
Dive—Stone, Calhoun.
Plunge--Howard, Hambleton.
220-Yard Swim—Bahlke, Stone.
Relay—Bahlke, Duning, Lord,
Welsh.
INSPECTORS AWAITED BY
R. 0. T. C. UNIT
As announced by Major Hoisington, commander of the Johns
Hopkins R. 0. T. C. unit, last
Thursday, February 21, the preliminary inspection of the War
Department to determine whether
the local unit is worthy of being
formally inspected in May will be
held during one of the drill periods of this week. The unit was
told by Major Hoisington to be
prepared fully for inspection at
both the Monday and Thursday
drill periods, as the officers from
Washington had not as yet decided as to which one Johns Hopkins
would be examined on.
This inspection is very important to the R. 0. T. C. Unit, as a
favorable report by the examining
officers will entitle it to an inspection to determine whether or not
Johns Hopkins University should
be designated in War Department
orders and publications as one of
the "Distinguished
Colleges."
This honor the University now
holds.
These preliminary inspections
are given by the War Department
in universities throughout the
country, so that the number of colleges to be examined in May is
fewer, and hence a more careful
and exhaustive inspection may be
given to each one.

dinner of the Y. M. C. A. will be
held at the Friends' Meeting
House, 3107 N. Charles Street, on
Tuesday, March 4, at 6:00 P. M.
Reservations can be made at the
"Y" Office at the Barn. The subscription is $.50 per plate.
Mr. Norman Thomas of New
York City will be the speaker.
His subject will be "The Labor
Movement and the Student." Mr.
Thomas is a graduate of Princeton University and of the Union
Theological Seminary. He has
been editor of "The World Tomorrow" and is now one of the
contributing editors of "The Nation". Mr. Thomas has a full understanding of his subject, according to Mr. Schall, "Y" secretary, for his writings have been
largely on labor topics, and, moreover he is head of "The League
for Industrial Democracy." Mr.
Schall says that the program for
this meeting should surpass any
previous one.
The annual election of the four
chief officers of the Y. M. C. A.
will take place as usual on March
The voting will be at the "Y"
office between the hours of 10:00
A. M. and 5:00 P. M., and from
5:00 P. M. to 6:00 P. M. at the
Friends Meeting House. The results will be made public at the
fellowship dinner.
The number of students present
nt the previous dinners makes it
imperative that the tickets be secured in advance.
Only those
that have .signed up at the "Y"
office before Monday afternoon
will be provided for.
BARNSTORMERS
HOLDING
SIX REHEARSALS A
WEEK AT BARN
Preparations for "The Galloper", by Richard Harding Davis,
to be presented at the Lyric by
the Hopkins Barnstormers' Club
on March 28 and 29, are proceeding at the rate of almost one rehearsal a day. To be exact. rehearsals are being held six times
a week.
Thus far, hov,cver, tt:e rehearsals have been more in the nature
of tryouts. According to present
indications, the two casts will not
be chosen within a week at least.
The Club's recently adopted plan
of casting provides that the final
cast will not be chosen until
about two weeks before the show
is given. Until then, the rehearsals will be in the nature of a
fight between the two casts.
Although a very satisfactory
number of men have responded
to the call for candidates, there
are still opportunities -open to a
number of would-be actors. The
feminine roles, especially, offer
good openings for any embryonic
Julian Eltinges.
Any belated Barrymores who
feel the call of the footlights can
yet show their wares at the tryouts. The rehearsal days are the
following: Monday, Tuesday,
Thursday, and Friday at 7:30 P.
M.; Saturday afternoon at 2
o'clock and Sunday afternoon at
3 o'clock.

When Louis Clarke entered
Johns Hopkins a few years ago,
few realized he was an athlete.
After scrubbing for a year on the
baseball team, the track management persuaded him to try out for
the track team. He succeeded in
breaking all Hopkins records for
the 100 and 220 yard dashes. Last
Saturday night, Clarke reached
the height of his career when he
broke the world's indoor mark for
100 yards when he flew over this
distance in 9 4-5 seconds. In barely three years a sprinter of record
ability was developed by Hopkins
track coaches.

ALUMNI REUNION HELD ON
EVENING OF FEBRUARY 22
The annual Alumni Reunion
held in the Alumni Memorial Dormitory on the evening of February 22 was a decided success. Not
quite as many of the "old grads"
showed up as were counted on,
but 160 made their appearance and
enjoyed to the fullest extent the
program of entertainment provided.
The Commons Hall of the Dormitory was tastefully and colorfully decorated with the class banners of graduating classes as far
back as '80 and '84. Here and
there were banners that showed
all too plainly the ravages of class
rushes and of time but all waved
proudly in the eddy of conversation and reminiscences that
poured unrestrained from the old
timers as well as the youngsters of
'22 and '23.
The principal speakers of the
evening were Dr. Weed, Dean of
the 'Medical School; Mr. Stuart
Janney; Dr. John Latane, retiring
Dean of the University; and Mr.
George Knapp. A short business
meeting was held at which Mr.
Robertson Griswold was elected
President of the Alumni Association. Music and smokes rounded
out a fully pleasurable evening.

It is a pity that all universities
not enjoying the Honor System
cannot send committees to investigate its workings at Johns Hopkins, Princeton, Washington and
Lee, and other institutions where
it has proved a success. The recent midyear examinations in
many colleges has again brought
the subject to the fore. A few
headlines from various papers
will show how grave a problem
cheating is in a very great many
colleges. For instance, "Faculty
Acts on Cheating in Exams," "Six
Men Brought Before Faculty
Committee" and "Reports Entirely Cribbed." These are from papers in colleges that enjoy very
good reputations. Yet at N. Y. U.
four members of the faculty profesed the belief that an Honor
System was not only impractical,
but undesirable.

PLAYSHOP INVITES UNDERGRADUATES TO SHOP
NIGHT
The Homewood Playshop will
hold, on Saturday March 1, its
third "Shop Night" of the year.
Several theatrical experiments
will be tried out. These "Shop
Nights" of the Playshop are the
Hopkins Theatrical laboratory periods. All members of the Playshop are invited and all undergraduates will be welcomed.
The Plays that will be tried out
are as follows: "Maneaters" by
McCauley; "The Fruit" by Gilbert Pouder ; and one act from a
Shakespearean play. With all the
dramatic talent now enrolled
under the Hopkins Playshop a
more than delightful evening may
be expected by visitors as the directorial and coaching staffs have
spent more than the ordinary
amount of time in the production
of these excellent playlets.

CIVIL
PARTMENT PROMISES COOPERATION IN ENGINEERING SHOW
The committee in charge of the
Engineering Show has recently
obtained from Prof. John H. Gregory, head of the Civil Engineering
Department, permission to put on
display all of the engineering apparatus belonging to that department. By means of this arrangement, the show as originally
planned will be augmented to almost twice its size. William
North Crout, president of the
American Society of Civil Engineers, who has been placed in
charge of the Civil Engineer's portion of the show, anounced that all
laboratories will be kept open during the two days of the shows In
the Highways Laboratory, there
will be run a number of standard
tests, such as the Dorey test for
hardness of paving material, the
Page impact test, and the Rattler
abrasion test. Samples of bituminous road materials and samples
of Portland cements will also be
put on display.
